segments.text: You'll need more under present circumstances that can be provided by the raw materials that you now have in your inventory.
So a determination has to be made of how much raw materials do you need in the long term?
And what do you do about getting them?
Because it's a very peculiar raw material, and it occurs in very minute quantities on the Earth's surface and in various forms.
And it is extremely costly to get and refine to start moving.
After a year's work on
That problem, it became evident that we were going to have to have one of the largest searches for the material that anybody could imagine in the United States.
And other places too, but primarily in the United States.
And that several different processes were going to have to be developed to bring the material out of its whatever state that it was in.
to uranium oxide, something that you could start to process in the system, and that this was going to be quite costly.
Then plans had to be made and rules made, laws made, to, as a way of implementing it.
And this is when there began to be rewards for
uranium of various concentrations, and we got the miners and the prospectors all stirred up out west and going over the hill, and sure enough we came up with the materials.
Did you work with the U.S. Geological Survey on this?
Oh, we worked with everybody.
Yes, them too, but mostly the AEC did most of it by itself.
We worked with everybody.
But there are all kinds of approaches to this.
For instance, in Florida, there's enough uranium in the phosphates down there that
was a substantial quantity of it.
But to use it, you have to refine it in such a way that you come out with a different kind of phosphate fertilizer than you're producing from there now.
So you have to re-educate all the farmers.
to the use of the new kind of fertilizer before you could make the thing even approach being economical.
So you do better to get your Randy Moore from some other sources, even though it's more costly, as long as you could do it.
There are a number of projects, use that as one example, there are a number of problems like that.
But we did develop a system that did get us the uranium we need.
And where did we get it from?
I thought we got our uranium from South America.
I mean South Africa.
South Africa, yes.
We got quite a bit of the initial uranium from South Africa.
And we're still getting some, at least as of the time I got out of the Patriot.
But not a great deal.
Most of it we get from
my own west, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, a lot of the mines out there are still rolling.
So that was one of the major issues.
That was one of the major early things, yes.
Of course, in the stories in the weapons development side of the thing that I really can't talk
completely fascinating.
All of the testing and whatnot.
As of the time I got left AC, I had seen and witnessed more nuclear detonations than anybody in the world except one man
who was in the AEC out there, or was in Los Alamos.
And he's not dead.
How many was there?
Ooh, I don't know.
I don't think I could even count them up.
Most people say three, four, five, six maybe.
I was probably somewhere around a hundred, I don't know exactly, but way up there.
Well, we're going to talk about those.
Some big ones.
We're going to talk about those and of course some of the implications of testing underground and above ground, but let's go back to the job as executive director.
What were some of the other issues besides
finding uranium, and as far as how many bombs are needed?
Well, the type of weapons, whether you build them for torpedoes, for example, whether you build them as bombs, whether you build them
the other delivery systems that come in, like the V-1s, the Army's gun, all those things were being considered at that time, and they were pretty hard.
Of course, the whole question of the Superbomb and the
hydrogen bomb and whatnot all came up during that length of time.
We got way over our head in cryogenics that we'd never been involved in before.
What are cryogenics?
Cryogenics is the science of low temperatures.
Most all of the stuff in connection with the H-bomb at that time had to be handled
minus 270 or minus 454 degrees Fahrenheit.
Have these tremendous duars that are filled with liquid nitrogen that you have to use to keep it to this temperature and keep it filled and make your own nitrogen in the process and fly this stuff.
It's a tremendous problem.
I forgot the basic thing I was talking about.
We're talking about the issues.
So just the H-bomb thing, if that dominated the whole thing, would be enough to keep you more than occupied during that period of time.
The testing, where can you test, how can you test, can you test above ground, underground,
of the testing and the radioactivity.
All of those were major issues during that period of time.
Tremendous problems on going forward on nuclear airplanes and that nuclear ramjet was a real problem during that period of time.
the time we had to acquire ARCO, Idaho, build that tremendous test station out there.
The other thing that we were trying to get going on then, the peaceful uses of it, particularly reactors.
We built the first reactors out there, and we built the first plutonium reactor out there.
The expansion of the diffusion plants to produce U-235 was a major issue.
The construction of additional reactors at the commission's facilities, particularly at Hanford, to produce more plutonium.
That was an issue.
Construction of Rocky Flats at Denver, another big one.
I was wondering about the relations between the AEC and the Department of Defense.
Well, overall they were generally not the best.
or in the early stages.

Not that there was something wrong with the people, but the whole philosophy of the United States at that time was to keep the military out of the atomic business, because everybody was scared of that.
They were looking for a peaceful world where there were no atomic bombs or no atomic threats.
All of which is great, but
Most of us couldn't see it going that way.
It just wasn't going that way.

The United Nations were being organized, and one of my jobs when I was on the Joint Strategic Plan staff was to serve as assistant to the military representative to the United Nations, military staff committee of the United Nations.
So while, and boy, if you talk about a frustrating experience, that is one of them.
And so there were many of us that just thought that we had to get along, and it made no difference whether we belonged to or not.
And we did, and worked at it hard.
And some of the commissioners were,
in a way, I mean, leaned in that direction.
Anti-military?
Well, not so much anti-military as they were going to put this thing peacefully to bed.
They weren't necessarily discrediting the military, but some way this couldn't have this bomb in a military application way.
Not all the commissioners felt that way, and since they worked hard to do their job, I have to give the commissioners credit, at least the early ones, because they worked real hard at it.
But as it went on down the road, the major user that AEC had, had to be defense.
There's all these other things, reactors, nuclear power, isotopes, all of the peaceful uses, all the wonderful things.
They are wonderful.
They're going to come, but as it turns out, it's going to take centuries rather than decades.
And so pretty soon, you're in bed with the military whether you like it or not, because that's really all you're doing.
And in the meantime, it's becoming urgently aware for everybody to see that it's essential for survival of the United States that you have a capability.
And so as these things become apparent,
then relations, of course, improved, improved, improved.
So they got to the point where we're working together very real well, real well.
At this time, in 1950, the North Koreans attacked South Korea, and I was wondering what impact that had on you people in the nuclear or in the atomic bomb business.
I don't really think it had any, because we were already geared up doing whatever we were going to do.
And the thing wasn't long enough, and the means used didn't impact us in such a way as to change what we were doing.
I'm sure that it caused the planners an awful lot of worry, but of course I wasn't in the planning then, I was in the doing.
So I don't think on the atomic side the impact was really, well there must have been some right this minute.
I don't think of what it might have been.
Okay.
Of course, just
a couple of years after that, we have the problem between the President and General MacArthur.
And I was wondering, well, he made some statements about actually using atomic weapons and bombing in Manchuria, and I was wondering what the Air Force thought about that.
I just don't know.
I wasn't in the Air Force at that time, and I don't honestly know.
but you were liaison between the Defense Department and the AEC, so was there any discussion, when he made statements like that, was there any discussion that you remember?
No, not between those agencies, no.
I'm sure there were plenty of discussions in the Joint Chiefs of Staff and those places,
that problem would not get to be a part of the military liaison committee.
Okay.
What was your personal opinion of firing the general?
Well, I regretted very much that it had to happen, insofar as the specifics were concerned.
I didn't know the answer, didn't know the fact, and so I just didn't have a proper opinion.
I've always thought that, even in retrospect, that Truman was a little bit hasty.
But also, I know MacArthur, and I can understand it.
I sure can understand it.
At this same time, of course, we have
the McCarthyism and the Red Scare period, and most government officials, if not all government officials, were supposed to sign loyalty pledges.
Were you supposed to sign one, and did you?
Well, let me see.
This program was started in 1947.
I would have without any qualms at the time, but it didn't bother me either way.
But I don't remember ever having to do it.
I feel pretty sure that I never did, never had occasion to sign one.
Senator McCarthy went after the Secretary of the Army, Stevens.
What was your opinion and other general officers' opinion in the Air Force?
People that you knew, your colleagues that you talked to.
Well, most of us just thought it was a way of McCarthy making a splash.
we thought Stevens had his shortcomings just like anybody else, but they weren't the kind of things that McCarthy was trying to prove.
And of course our sympathy was all for Stevens and getting him cleared and back on his job.
And I detested the McCarthy approach to the thing.
I don't know.
That brought into question the whole patriotism
Yes, that's what it amounts to.
Of course, that's not right.
The armed services are patriotic enough.
They'll stand.
And we detested the whole damn thing, but there wasn't anything we could do about it except stand on the sidelines.
In 1951 you switched jobs.
Why was that?
You became deputy chief of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, a project which later in 1954 you became chief in which you stayed for six and a half years.
Did you get two stars then?
Well why did you switch and tell me about getting two stars.
An Air Force officer on duty in Washington really should grow out of his job in three years.
If he doesn't, maybe better start looking at him.
And I was trying to grow, and I thought I had done about all I could do with the MLC job.

By that time, the relationship between the Department of Defense and AEC had developed to such an extent that the Multilateral Liaison Committee wasn't really necessary anymore, except as a channel, as a conduit and a postdoc.
And as a matter of fact, I had
reduced the staff to recognize this and didn't have very much of a staff left.
So, I thought it's time to get out and turn over to something else.
The Armed Forces Special Weapons Project was the place I went as deputy commander.
And it was a project born

When the Atomic Energy Commission was created, there were a number of residual functions connected with atomic energy that need to or had to, as the case may be, stay in the military, in the Department of Defense.
They set up this agency to take care of that and left General Groves in command of it and made it answerable to the three chiefs of staff separately, Chief of Staff, Army, Navy, Air Force.
And it operated that way.

It's had many jobs, but its two big jobs were to take the orders approved through the military liaison committee and the commission for weapons, and to see that they were produced in accordance with those specifications.

and to determine any characteristics of the weapons that were necessary to determine in the process, to accept those weapons when they were produced, to take care of them and store them and have custody of them and keep anybody else from having custody of them.
which turns out to be a pretty damn big order before you get through it.
The other major job they had was to take whatever actions were necessary to develop a comprehensive handbook of the effects of atomic weapons on all kinds of targets and materials and other things.
And so we handled
all of the atomic weapons effects tests and participation in testing, military participation in testing.
I had a headquarters in Washington in the Pentagon and a field command at Sandia Base in Albuquerque, New Mexico, adjacent to the Sandia Corporation out there.
And then various weapons storage, repair, and rehabilitation places all over the United States that we built.
I built five of them myself.
And so I took over as deputy to General Loper, who was an Army general.
So that first
Two and a half or three years, I've forgotten exactly.
Three years.
And then he retired and I took it over.
For another three years.
And as of the time that Engine Charlie Wilson came into defense, he took it out from under the chiefs of the three services and put it under the Secretary of Defense.
So I answered to him.
And what difference did that make?
I mean, did that make a difference?
Instead of you being under the JCS, now you're under the Secretary of Defense?
Yes, I wasn't under the JCS.
I was under the services individually.
Oh, you were under each service individually.
Each service.
I was responsible to the chief of naval operations, chief of staff of the Air Force, chief of staff of the Army.
So it was probably a little bit more cumbersome then, wasn't it?
Well, it really wasn't.
If you've got the kind of personality and confidence to work in it, it makes it real easy.
Because what you did is go and sit down and talk with them about their problems and write them a letter to tell them that's what you're going to do.
an initial letter and sent it back to you and that's all you got.
Well why did Wilson change it then?
Was it an attempt to make it more streamlined?
Well you may remember when he went in there there was a lot of talk about the military, the generals running every damn thing in Washington and why not.
You go through these cycles all the time.
Roger Kyes was his deputy.
I don't know if you know him or not.
No, I don't.
How do you spell his name?
K-e-y-e-s. Kyes, he calls it.
He was in command of the Chevrolet division of General Motors.
That makes sense.
He came in as his deputy, and he ate General's breakfast, you see.
far as the stories go.
Great big guy, about six foot four I suspect, four or five.
Ugliest man I ever saw in my life.
Gruff, gruff as hell.
But a real fine guy.
Fine in what way?
Well, he make a hell of a lot of noise and stir up a lot of things, but if he believed in you, and you said this is the way it is, by God, he'd go die for that.
I had to go and see Wilson about something, and I've forgotten what the hell it was.
I got to talking to guys while I was up there.
And then he wanted a presentation about what this outfit did, what we were doing down there.
So I told him I would be up whenever it was.
He asked me sometime next day.
And I'd have some charts showing where it fit in the organization.
And I went up and explained the whole damn thing to him.
He was so fascinated by it, because he didn't know anything about that business, that he called Wilson to come in and sit down and have me go through the whole damn thing again.
So I took there a whole afternoon, a busy afternoon it was.
At least for me it was.
When I got through, Wilson said, I think that's something we ought to run from up here.
I don't know what happened after that, but it was run from up there.
It wasn't any real problem.
I knew what the chiefs wanted and I kept them informed and I did that.
There wasn't much argument about
The real touchy part was, who had the weapons and were they being taken care of?
And I knew the answer to that, so was everybody else.
It wasn't a real problem.
You had to be diplomatic, and you had to honor everybody's desires.
If it fit, if it didn't, why tell them so?
And they'd haul in.
A real fine bunch of gentlemen to work with, anyway.
Well, I want to talk a little bit about, can you tell me about Wilson?
Engine Charlie?
Well, from that point on, I got to know him better.
spent some time with him on some of his long trips.
I went out to, and we talked with him, to some of the nuclear tests.
And it's a hell of a long ways out there.
You can do a little bit of talking.
Sure.
And then saw him on strictly business, of course, quite often back here in the Pentagon.
A real fine man, a very able man.
We were beginning to get the kind of policies in the United States by the time he was in there that made it awful hard for a Secretary of Defense to really do the job.
Because a lot of people want the Defense Department dismantled, and you have to fight like the devil for any kind of money that you need to do something with.
And it became harder and harder and harder for him to get moving, to keep a defense establishment like he thought it ought to be.
What kind of administrator was he?
I guess that wasn't clear, except that he left most of it to Roger Kye.
And Kye was pretty damn good, as long as everybody did what he told them.
If they didn't, he fired them.
And as long as they get by with that, well, that works.
There are some people you can't fire.
It gets to be a problem.
And he hit that kind of problem.
Well, when was that?
In the latter part of the administration.
He tried to fire a general?
No, no, he could fire the general.
That's what I thought.
But he tried to fire a political appointee.
Yeah, and he got crossed up with.
What about General Groves?
Well, Donald Groves was a, what about him and what kind of man was he?
Yeah, what kind of man was he?
What type of administrator was he?
What type of relations did you have with him?
He was a fine administrator for the kind of problem he had, and of course I guess that's the definition of a good administrator.
I don't think that under the kind of problems we have administering something now, with a war not going on or no urgency or whatnot, he probably would not have shined as an administrator.
But people had to do what he told them to do at that time and did.
And he did, he told them the right thing.
They did a hell of a good job.
I'd have to say he's a very good administrator for the job that he had.
And of course it was a very difficult job because of the kind of people that had to have working for you and the fact that it was all so secret that nobody could know anything.
So I think he did a good job and was a good man.
And I didn't know him until after all this was over and OPSWAP was created and he's head of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Party.
In other words, in 1 January of 47, or late 46.
I might have known him a little bit, but after that I did.
And then I had him as my consultant and
after he retired and left, both while I was in Ashwaub and later in the Atomic Energy Commission.
So I got to know him quite well and I got to admire him.
What did you admire about him?
His absolute determination for one thing.
If there wasn't one way to skin the cat, he could find some other one and do it.
He believed what he believed and nothing shook it.
He was persistent and worked at whatever objective he had in mind, really worked at it.
And he was a very intelligent guy, somebody very interesting to talk to, interesting to discuss things with, and had views on everything.
So I liked him.
Now there's another man that I want to talk about, who although you at this time weren't involved in this, still and the Air Force itself you weren't that involved with.
I'm interested in Curtis LeMay and the problems of the rise of the Strategic Air Command.
You must have had some relations with LeMay.
You must have heard stories about him or formed some opinion about him and the Strategic Air Command.
There are even movies about SAC in the 1950s.
It was glorified.
What were your feelings about that?
Well,
I guess LeMay was a major, captain or major, when I first met him.
And that was in connection with these navigation flights back in 1937 off the West Coast.
And I didn't know him very well, but he was
one of the four or five qualified celestial navigators that we had, as well as pilot and all the other things.
He was entrusted with the secrets of the most secret thing we had at that time, a northern bomb site.
And so I kind of held him in awe as a new second lieutenant.
But then I didn't know anything more about him until the B-29s and I was in India in the position we've already talked about.
And we planned and built for and accommodated
the B-29 operations out of India, through China, against Japan, and back down that route.
And, of course, LeMay was in command of that.
So, I got to know him and deal with him in India quite a bit on

Well, the mundane things, logistic support and how do you hell do you get gasoline to Chengdu, and how can we get Chiang Kai-shek to get another million coolies fixing the runway, and this sort of thing.
I got to like him pretty well, but he's not the kind of guy you get close to, or that I get close to, anyhow.
Then, back in Washington, he was there before he went to Tsai.
And after, too, for that matter, but before, when he was there.
We did a lot of skate shooting together, and I got to know him that way.
Then when I was in MLC and later in AFSWAP, of course I dealt directly with him while he was in command of SAC, and I knew a lot about their problems out there.
And while he disconcerts some people about, like his remark about Hanoi, I bet you back into the Stone Age,
In retrospect, what better could you have done?
So, I don't feel it's as crude as people feel it is.
I think it's a little more reasoned than that.
But he is a hard man, a damn hard man.
He's a hard man to know.
But he does mean what he says, and he made a fighting force that
I think kept this country so it didn't have to go to war for a while.
Because that's all we had.
We didn't have another thing to fight with.
And when you take it, those crews set up a third of them airborne at a time around the
Boy, that is a killer.
That is a killing operation.
And he was able to do it, he was able to get his crews to do it, he got them to believe in it, and they did a very good job of it.
And that's a good commander in my book.
Now, of course, there was some problems between
tactical air command and strategic air command.
Were you at all involved with that?
Well, yeah, but that's just a running thing that goes on all the time.
It isn't really something to worry too much about, I don't think.
It's real serious to the guy who isn't getting the money in that year's budget to get his airplanes, and he believes what he says and feels strongly about it and fights about it, and good for him.
But it isn't really, they're not fighting each other's missions.
They're just fighting for the resources they think they need to do their job.
So I don't really pay much attention to those.
Spike Mollmeyer had tack and got it organized and got it going.
And I'm sure he had arguments with everybody, but he'd fight a circle saw if he needed to to get one more airplane or one more whatever he needed.
to make a, make his command go.
So, I don't think there's anything serious about those kind of fights.
Well, I think that what we ought to do is, is stop here and get together again.
Very good, very good.
I am terribly sorry about the last time, because
